title: Authors and Citation
text: Gohel D (2025). rvg: R Graphics Devices 'Office' Vector Graphics Output. R package version 0.4.0, https://ardata-fr.github.io/officeverse/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rvg: R Graphics Devices for 'Office' Vector Graphics Output},   author = {David Gohel},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.4.0},   url = {https://ardata-fr.github.io/officeverse/}, }

what: R Graphics Devices for Office Vector Graphics Output
title: R Graphics Devices for Office Vector Graphics Output
text: rvg providing two graphics devices produces Vector Graphics outputs DrawingML format Microsoft PowerPoint dml_pptx Microsoft Excel dml_xlsx. Theses formats let users edit graphic elements (editable graphics) within PowerPoint Excel good rendering. raw XML outputs used . Functions dml ph_with() used package officer add vector graphics PowerPoint documents (dml function simple wrapper mark plot instructions Vector Graphics instructions). Function xl_add_vg() equivalent Excel workbooks. default, theses graphics editable, element edition can disabled option editable = FALSE.
code: library(rvg) library(ggplot2) library(officer)  my_vec_graph <- dml(code = barplot(1:5, col = 2:6))  doc <- read_pptx() doc <- add_slide(doc, layout = "Title and Content", master = "Office Theme") doc <- ph_with(doc, my_vec_graph, location = ph_location_fullsize() ) print(doc, target = "my_plot.pptx") doc <- read_xlsx() doc <- xl_add_vg(doc, sheet = "Feuil1", code = print(gg),    width = 6, height = 6, left = 1, top = 2 ) print(doc, target = "vg.xlsx")

title: R Graphics Devices for Office Vector Graphics Output
text: can get development version GitHub: Install CRAN version:

what: Wrap plot instructions for DrawingML plotting in Powerpoint — dml
title: Wrap plot instructions for DrawingML plotting in Powerpoint — dml
text: simple wrapper mark plot instructions Vector Graphics instructions. produces object class 'dml' corresponding method ph_with. function enable usage R plot argument code ggplot objects argument ggobj.

title: Wrap plot instructions for DrawingML plotting in Powerpoint — dml
code: dml(   code,   ggobj = NULL,   bg = "white",   fonts = list(),   pointsize = 12,   editable = TRUE,   ... )

title: Wrap plot instructions for DrawingML plotting in Powerpoint — dml
text: code plotting instructions ggobj ggplot object print. argument code ignored argument supplied. bg, fonts, pointsize, editable Parameters passed dml_pptx ... unused arguments

title: Wrap plot instructions for DrawingML plotting in Powerpoint — dml
text: dealing ggplot object argument bg effect ggplot theme specifying background color, forget define colors want theme:

title: Wrap plot instructions for DrawingML plotting in Powerpoint — dml
code: anyplot <- dml(code = barplot(1:5, col = 2:6), bg = "wheat")  library(officer) doc <- read_pptx() doc <- add_slide(doc, "Title and Content", "Office Theme") doc <- ph_with(doc, anyplot, location = ph_location_fullsize()) fileout <- tempfile(fileext = ".pptx") # fileout <- "vg.pptx" print(doc, target = fileout)

what: DrawingML graphic device for Microsoft PowerPoint — dml_pptx
title: DrawingML graphic device for Microsoft PowerPoint — dml_pptx
text: Graphics devices Microsoft PowerPoint DrawingML format.

title: DrawingML graphic device for Microsoft PowerPoint — dml_pptx
code: dml_pptx(   file = "Rplots.dml",   width = 6,   height = 6,   offx = 1,   offy = 1,   bg = "white",   fonts = list(),   pointsize = 12,   editable = TRUE,   id = 1L,   last_rel_id = 1L,   raster_prefix = "raster_",   standalone = TRUE )

title: DrawingML graphic device for Microsoft PowerPoint — dml_pptx
text: file file output appear. height, width Height width inches. offx, offy top left origin plot bg Default background color plot (defaults "white"). fonts Named list font names aliased fonts installed system. unspecified, R default families sans, serif, mono symbol aliased family returned match_family(). use specific fonts, need font installed system. can check package gdtools function gdtools::font_family_exists(). example: list(sans = "Roboto", serif = "Times", mono = "Courier"). pointsize default point size. editable vector graphics elements (points, text, etc.) editable. id specifies unique identifier (integer) within slide contain DrawingML instructions. last_rel_id specifies last unique identifier (integer) within relationship file used reference embedded raster images . raster_prefix string value used prefix png files produced raster objects printed graphical device. standalone produce standalone drawingml file? FALSE, omits xml header namespaces.

title: DrawingML graphic device for Microsoft PowerPoint — dml_pptx
code: # \donttest{ dml_pptx(file = tempfile()) plot(1:11, (-5:5)^2, type = "b", main = "Simple Example") dev.off() #> agg_record_432744511  #>                    2  # }

FALSE, omits xml header namespaces.

title: add a plot output as vector graphics into a PowerPoint object — ph_with.dml
code: anyplot <- dml(code = barplot(1:5, col = 2:6), bg = "wheat")  library(officer) doc <- read_pptx() doc <- add_slide(doc, "Title and Content", "Office Theme") doc <- ph_with(doc, anyplot, location = ph_location_fullsize())  fileout <- tempfile(fileext = ".pptx") print(doc, target = fileout)

what: add a plot output as vector graphics into an Excel object — xl_add_vg
title: add a plot output as vector graphics into an Excel object — xl_add_vg
text: produces vector graphics output R plot instructions add result Excel sheet. read_xlsx.

title: add a plot output as vector graphics into an Excel object — xl_add_vg
code: xl_add_vg(x, sheet, code, left, top, width, height, ...)

title: add a plot output as vector graphics into an Excel object — xl_add_vg
text: x rxlsx object produced officer::read_xlsx sheet sheet label/name code plot instructions left, top left top origin plot slide inches. height, width Height width inches. ... arguments passed dml_xlsx.

title: add a plot output as vector graphics into an Excel object — xl_add_vg
code: # \donttest{ library(officer) my_ws <- read_xlsx() my_ws <- xl_add_vg(my_ws,   sheet = "Feuil1",   code = barplot(1:5, col = 2:6), width = 6, height = 6, left = 1, top = 2 ) fileout <- tempfile(fileext = ".xlsx") print(my_ws, target = fileout) # }
